Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing 125 I Seed and Hookwire Localization in Breast-Conserving Surgery

Background: This multicentre randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of 125 I seed versus hookwire localization in reducing re-excision and positive margin rates in breast-conserving surgery for non-palpable breast cancer.

Methods: Conducted from September 2013 to March 2018, 690 women with non-palpable breast cancer eligible for breast-conserving surgery were randomised to receive preoperative localization using either 125 I seeds or hookwires across eight sites. Randomization was stratified by lesion type and study site, with allocation concealed via a secure online database. The primary outcomes were re-excision and positive margin rates, assessed post-surgery. Secondary outcomes included resection volumes and weights. The analysis was performed on an intention-to-treat basis.

Results: Of the 690 women randomised, 659 were analysed (327 in the 125 I seed group and 332 in the HWL group). The mean age was 60.3 years in the 125 I seed group and 60.7 years in the HWL group. The re-excision rate was significantly lower in the 125 I seed group compared to the HWL group (13.9% vs. 18.9%; p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed in positive margin rates or specimen weights and volumes. Adverse events included suboptimal positioning requiring corrective action in 9 cases for seeds and 13 for wires. No cases of seed migration were reported.

Interpretation: 125 I seed localization significantly reduced re-excision rates compared to HWL in breast-conserving surgery, demonstrating its potential for improved surgical outcomes. Trial registration: ACTRN12613000655741. Funding: Not specified.
